<s>Glen<\s> Strath Fillan, about 1½ mile south of Tyndrum, where
a vertical foliation runs about N50E through a hard & very
quartzose Gneiss: the same perpendicular plane runs
N45E through Ben Lawers, N60E at the ridge between
Strath Tay and Glen Tummel <s>at<\s> a little to the east of
Schehallion, <s>&<\s> crosses the pass of Killicrankie in a
direction very little north of east, & runs N35E
across Glen Shee, about a mile below the Spittal.
As a line drawn N50E from the western point observed in
<s>Glen<\s> Strath Fillan to Killicrankie passes through the
intermediate spots named, <s>it seems to<\s> and gives N50E
as the general bearing of this vertical plane of
foliation, leaving out of account the observation in Glen
Shee where the plane seems to have been thrown to the
south by some local disturbance. **(Addition opposite)
The next arch which crosses the Highlands <s>is formed
has a<\s> with a diameter of between 25 & 30 miles runs <s>along<\s> for the most
part through Gneiss: its southern boundary coincides
with the northern boundary of the arch just described;
I only observed on two points the <s>the plane of<\s> perpendicular foliation
which forms its northern limit: two perpendicular
planes about a mile apart bearing N40E cross the valley of the
Spey <s>a little to the east of<\s> the junction of the road
from Loch Laggan with that which runs down
Strath Spey, from which spot they run on through
Corbuie into the line of the Monaglea Mountains;
I observed the perpendicular again in those Mountains
4 miles NW of Kingussie, where the regularity
of its course was destroyed by the intrusion of a
